sequences: Australia has a strong tradition of an honest days pay for an honest days work. We have a strong union presence which leads to high wages backed by a strong resource economy. We also have a very multicultural society with many immigrants choosing to settle in Australia this leads to diverse shopping areas where goods originally made all over the world are made right here on our shores. The main reason Australia is the best country in the world is our heavily ingrained concept of a "fair go" meaning you give anybody a chance to prove themselves no matter who they are. This is not even mentioning our spectacular landscapes and beaches. All in all Australia is the best country in the world.

Australia has a rich tradition of earning an honest day's pay for an honest day's work. Our strong union presence contributes to high wages, supported by a robust resource economy. Additionally, we take pride in our multicultural society, with many immigrants choosing to make Australia their home. This diversity enriches our shopping areas, where products originally from around the globe are now made right here on our shores. One of the key reasons Australia stands out as the best country in the world is our deeply ingrained belief in a "fair go," which emphasizes giving everyone a chance to prove themselves, regardless of their background. And let's not overlook our breathtaking landscapes and stunning beaches. In summary, Australia truly is the best country in the world.

If something is important enough to cover in a website, then it should be easily found within the core content of the site and not shoved into an FAQ section. I think people only ever turn to FAQ pages if rhey can't find what they want within the main site. When clients demand an FAQ page, I will challenge this and ask them to rethink what should be in the core copy and what is irrelevant. If the information is already within the main content, and they still want an FAQ section, they are just adding unnecessary repetition into the content. Websites should Never include an FAQ section and I cant find an argument to support their use other than improving SEO. Change my view.

If a topic is significant enough to be included on a website, it should be easily accessible within the main content rather than relegated to an FAQ section. People typically resort to FAQ pages only when they cannot find the information they seek in the primary content. When clients request an FAQ page, I often challenge them to reconsider what truly belongs in the core copy versus what may be extraneous. If the information is already present in the main content and they still insist on having an FAQ section, it merely introduces unnecessary repetition. I believe that websites should avoid FAQ sections altogether, as I struggle to find a compelling justification for their existence beyond potential SEO benefits. I welcome any perspective that might change my view.

If the information is already included in the main content and they still insist on having an FAQ section, it creates unnecessary repetition. I believe websites should generally avoid FAQ sections, as I find it challenging to justify their existence beyond potential SEO advantages. I am open to any perspectives that might challenge my viewpoint.

Hell, some parts of land are still uncharted! I believe that large scale ocean exploration could also be a great testing ground for space exploration technology, as we already train astronauts underwater. I might even go so far as to say that we will see populated underwater colonies BEFORE we ever see populated spaceplanetary colonies. EDIT: Just to spark more thought Let the shift in thought begin!

I envision giant squid calamari—delicious! It seems to me that fiction has led the general public to focus excessively on colonizing outer space, while we have yet to fully explore our oceans. In fact, there are still uncharted areas of land! I believe that large-scale ocean exploration could serve as an excellent testing ground for space exploration technology, especially since we already conduct astronaut training underwater. I would even argue that we may witness the establishment of populated underwater colonies before we see any inhabited colonies on other planets. EDIT: Just to inspire further reflection, let the shift in thinking commence!

In fact, I would contend that we might see populated underwater colonies emerge before we establish any inhabited settlements on other planets. EDIT: Let this inspire deeper contemplation and spark a shift in perspective!

I think that foreign direct investment in general is sound practice and benefits both parties, but have recently had many people say its a bad thing but without being able to explain any sound reasoning. Current example which has brought the issue up is the talks of Indonesian purchase of land for cattle farming in Australia: Australia benefits from increased taxes, extra jobs, development of Australian agricultural industry, repairs damage from hastily putting a temporary ban on live cattle transport. Indonesia gets a guaranteed source of cattle, gets a return on their investment, learns from any farming techniques they learn from Australian farmers they hire. Change my view

I believe that foreign direct investment is generally a beneficial practice for both parties involved. However, I've recently encountered numerous individuals who criticize it without providing any solid reasoning. A current example that has sparked this discussion is the potential Indonesian purchase of land for cattle farming in Australia. This arrangement offers several advantages: Australia stands to gain from increased tax revenue, job creation, and the development of its agricultural sector, while also addressing the repercussions of a previous temporary ban on live cattle transport. On the other hand, Indonesia would secure a reliable source of cattle, achieve a return on its investment, and acquire valuable farming techniques from Australian farmers they employ. I invite you to challenge my perspective.

I believe that foreign direct investment is generally advantageous for both parties involved. However, I have recently encountered many individuals who criticize this practice without offering any substantive reasoning. A current example that has ignited this discussion is the potential Indonesian purchase of land for cattle farming in Australia. This arrangement presents several benefits: Australia would gain increased tax revenue, job creation, and advancements in its agricultural sector, while also addressing the consequences of a prior temporary ban on live cattle transport. Conversely, Indonesia would secure a dependable source of cattle, achieve a return on its investment, and gain valuable farming techniques from the Australian farmers they employ. I welcome any challenges to my viewpoint.

This arrangement presents several advantages: Australia stands to gain increased tax revenue, job creation, and advancements in its agricultural sector, while also addressing the consequences of a previous temporary ban on live cattle transport. Conversely, Indonesia would secure a reliable source of cattle, achieve a return on its investment, and gain valuable farming techniques from the Australian farmers they employ. I welcome any challenges to my perspective.

First, it's late to the party, commissioned in 1944 when the war is nearly over. Still, looks like a [normal carrier, right?] Well not so fast. Pan up a little [and you see the problem.] What's that huge number on the deck? Uh oh. And then of course we know what happened next, with the fires, and the infernos, and the hundreds of people dying, and the CO charging everyone with desertion, and being only one of two Essex class carriers to not go on to have a career after the war. There's just no way you can say this was a lucky ship.

First, it arrived late to the scene, commissioned in 1944 when the war was nearly over. At first glance, it appears to be a typical carrier, right? But not so fast. If you look a little closer, you'll notice a significant issue. What’s that enormous number on the deck? Uh oh. We all know what happened next: the fires, the infernos, the tragic loss of hundreds of lives, and the commanding officer accusing everyone of desertion. It’s worth noting that this ship was one of only two Essex-class carriers that did not have a post-war career. There's simply no way to describe this as a fortunate ship.

When it comes to fedoras, I don’t see how they differ from other formal hats. Personally, I wouldn’t wear one unless I were dressing up as a mobster or someone from the 1950s. If I see a celebrity, like a member of Fall Out Boy, wearing a fedora with style, I won’t feel embarrassed. However, the situation changes if I encounter someone who fits a particular stereotype—such as an overweight individual with a neckbeard, dressed in sneakers, shorts, a t-shirt, and a fedora. As for memes, I genuinely struggle to understand the negativity directed at them. What, exactly, is so objectionable about them?

Ok, I get that 90 of reddit is " left and liberal " but it's astonishing how often reddit idolizes someone simply because that person is gay, I believe that it takes more than a sexual preference to earn respect , I get that some gay people feel " oppressed " but the sheer amount of recognition they get for this is astonishing. why is it such a big deal and why do people so often " hop on the karma train " because of this, the amount of commenting about Russia and the Olympics being " oppressive " is mad , its borderline retarded how sheep like 90 of reddit is

I understand that a significant portion of Reddit leans left and liberal, but it's surprising how frequently individuals are idolized solely for being gay. I believe that respect should be earned through more than just sexual orientation. While I recognize that some members of the LGBTQ+ community feel oppressed, the extensive recognition they receive can be overwhelming. Why does this become such a major issue, and why do so many people seem to "jump on the bandwagon" in support? The amount of commentary regarding Russia and the Olympics being "oppressive" is quite excessive. It seems that many users on Reddit follow popular opinions without critical thought.

Currently, there are a variety of benefits offered to US military veterans. So many that there is an entire department, the Department of Veterans Affairs, responsible for overseeing them. Additionally, many veterans don't take advantage of these services due to ignorance about them andor being unwilling to go through the bureaucracy to get the benefits. I think both veterans and taxpayers would be better served by eliminating the Department of Veterans Affairs and instead paying soldiers a larger wage. They can then use these wages to obtain the type of services the current veterans benefits provided them, or perhaps to a better use depending on their individual lives and circumstances. Taxpayers also benefit by saving all of the operational costs used to implement the current benefit programs. Change my view!

There are currently numerous benefits available to U.S. military veterans, so many that an entire agency, the Department of Veterans Affairs, is dedicated to managing them. However, many veterans do not take advantage of these services, often due to a lack of awareness or a reluctance to navigate the complex bureaucracy involved in accessing benefits. I believe that both veterans and taxpayers would be better served by dismantling the Department of Veterans Affairs and instead providing service members with higher salaries. This approach would allow veterans to use their earnings to access the services they need, or to invest in alternatives that better suit their individual circumstances. Additionally, taxpayers would benefit from reduced operational costs associated with the current benefit programs. I challenge you to change my perspective!

I think it is condescending and silly for Canadian broadcasters on radio and television to be forced to play at least 30 Canadian content, meaning content created by Canadians or about Canada. I understand the governments desire to create a separate culture from the States, but I find it a little pointless, it will only drive people to use the increasingly availisble internet radio and satalite to bypass Canadian content all together. It also drives down the variety of content played as broadcasters still need to play popular favorites, but there are a lot less to choose from, causing good content to be repeated endlessly. So if there is something I'm missing that would make this a good idea, please CMV.

I find it condescending and somewhat misguided for Canadian broadcasters, both on radio and television, to be mandated to air at least 30% Canadian content, which refers to material created by Canadians or about Canada. While I understand the government's intention to foster a distinct culture separate from that of the United States, I believe this approach is ultimately counterproductive. It may drive listeners toward the increasingly accessible options of internet radio and satellite services, allowing them to bypass Canadian content entirely. Furthermore, this requirement limits the diversity of programming, as broadcasters still feel compelled to feature popular favorites, but with a narrower selection available, leading to the repetitive airing of the same few pieces. If there's an aspect of this policy that I might be overlooking which would justify its existence, I invite you to share your perspective.

I have this incredibly strange idea that going to an Ivy League school, or a highly ranked Technical school like Cal Tech and MIT promises intelligent student and brighter students than a state university. This is an issue for me, personally, because I am cautious of who I befriend now at my current University. I even beat myself up over the fact that I didn't apply to them myself in high school even though I decided to come to the school I chose for their film program. Even though, I'm happy with where I am! Please help me get out of this mindset, and understand that education doesn't make the person.

I have this rather peculiar belief that attending an Ivy League school or a prestigious technical institution like Caltech or MIT guarantees a more intelligent and capable student body compared to a state university. This mindset poses a personal challenge for me, as I find myself being selective about the friendships I form at my current university. I often regret not applying to those top schools in high school, despite my decision to choose my current institution for its film program. However, I am genuinely happy with where I am! I would appreciate any guidance on how to shift this perspective and recognize that education does not define a person's worth.

So I pirate a decent amount of software movies. I also go out to a lot of movies with friends and pay for games (concerts as well). Many times the money seems to end up in a rich execs pocket or lil Wayne's money stack. There's also the argument that if a company who supposedly screws it's customers (EA Ubisoft etc) then I shouldn't be willing to give them money. I understand that this could hurt the average joe at a company, but does it really a substantial amount? Most of the time I pirate something is because I just don't make a ton of money and would honestly rather put the money towards my shitty millennial retirement than video games.

I admit that I do pirate a fair amount of software and movies. However, I also enjoy going out to the cinema with friends and purchasing games and concert tickets. Often, it feels like the money I spend ends up in the pockets of wealthy executives or artists like Lil Wayne. Additionally, there's the perspective that if a company, such as EA or Ubisoft, treats its customers poorly, I shouldn't feel inclined to support them financially. I realize that this might negatively impact the average employee at these companies, but I wonder how significant that impact truly is. Most of the time, I resort to piracy because my income is limited, and I would rather invest my money in my future rather than on video games.

I understand that this may adversely affect the average employee at these companies, but I question how significant that impact truly is. Most of the time, I turn to piracy because my income is limited, and I prefer to invest my money in my future rather than on video games.

I don't see any reason to hold your country in higher regard simply because you were born within the arbitrary lines that define it. I think patriotism leads to ethnocentrism and a very skewed perception of the entire world where your country is perfect and many others are evil. I'm not saying that supporting your country is wrong in a situation you feel they're doing good. I'm not saying you can't love your country. I just think blind faith in your leaders allows atrocities to happen while excusing you or your leaders from ever admitting them.

I see no justification for holding your country in higher esteem simply because you were born within its arbitrary borders. I believe that patriotism can foster ethnocentrism and create a distorted view of the world, where one's own country is perceived as flawless while others are labeled as malevolent. I'm not suggesting that supporting your country is inherently wrong, especially when it is acting for the greater good. Nor am I saying that you cannot love your country. However, I do think that blind loyalty to your leaders can enable atrocities to occur, allowing both you and your leaders to evade accountability for such actions.

I'm not implying that supporting your country is inherently wrong, particularly when it is acting for the greater good. Nor am I suggesting that you cannot love your country. However, I believe that blind loyalty to your leaders can facilitate atrocities, allowing both you and your leaders to escape accountability for such actions.

Testosterone aromatization in the early stages of infancy is one of the least understood processes of human development. The levels of free testosterone in a mother's womb have been shown to impact cognitive development , enhancing "autistic" traits in people exposed to high levels. Female fetuses have shown high levels of alpha feto-protien, which binds to the estrogen associated with "masculating" the brains of male infants. Kalat JW (2009). "Reproductive behaviors." Biological psychology. Belmont, Calif: Wadsworth, Cengage Learning. p. 321. ISBN 0-495-60300-7 I believe the levels of AFP or aromatase are the best targets for early autism detection, as these proteins are at the front lines when it comes to masculinity and the associated cognitive development.

Testosterone aromatization during the early stages of infancy is one of the least understood processes in human development. Research indicates that elevated levels of free testosterone in the womb can influence cognitive development, potentially enhancing "autistic" traits in individuals exposed to high levels. Additionally, female fetuses exhibit high levels of alpha-fetoprotein (AFP), which binds to estrogen and is linked to the masculinization of male infants' brains. According to Kalat JW (2009) in "Reproductive Behaviors" (Biological Psychology, Belmont, Calif: Wadsworth, Cengage Learning, p. 321, ISBN 0-495-60300-7), I believe that monitoring levels of AFP or aromatase could be crucial for the early detection of autism, as these proteins play a significant role in masculinity and its associated cognitive development.

For the most part, people use the word "manipulation" to paint with too wide a brush. Disciplining my child is an attempt to manipulate them into good behavior. Emotional manipulation is a way to inspire good behavior in others, and can be a completely valid way to create good social morality. Without pressure from others, many people may never put forth personal effort. Obviously there can be negative manipulation, when a narcissistic person attempts to control the behaviors of others without any regard for the other person. This is what people usually mean when they speak of "manipulation" but they have deluded themselves that any effort to put a check on the behavior of others is also bad. You can and should manipulate people for their own good, especially those closest to you.

Often, people use the term "manipulation" too broadly. For instance, when I discipline my child, I am attempting to guide them toward good behavior. Emotional manipulation can serve as a means to encourage positive behavior in others and can be a legitimate way to foster social morality. Without some external influence, many individuals may lack the motivation to strive for personal improvement. While it’s true that negative manipulation exists—such as when a narcissistic person seeks to control others without any consideration for their well-being—this is typically what people refer to when they discuss "manipulation." However, many mistakenly believe that any effort to guide the behavior of others is inherently wrong. In reality, it is both acceptable and beneficial to influence others for their own good, particularly those closest to you.

The term "manipulation" is often used too broadly. For example, when I discipline my child, my intention is to guide them toward positive behavior. Emotional manipulation can be a valid way to encourage good behavior in others and can help promote social morality. Many individuals may struggle to find the motivation for personal improvement without some form of external influence. While negative manipulation certainly exists—such as when a narcissistic person seeks to control others without regard for their well-being—this is typically what people mean when they talk about "manipulation." However, many mistakenly believe that any attempt to guide the behavior of others is inherently wrong. In truth, it is both acceptable and beneficial to influence others for their own good, especially those who are closest to you.

I believe that, in general, the government should spend on programs that are either cannot be trusted to private organizations (police, emergency services) or are essential for a free economy (public roads and ports). A federal postal service does not fall into either of these categories, as it is not required to stop monopolies, and private companies have already shown that they can handle the business. It may have once been necessary, but is now a relic and a waste of funding. The best CMVs in this case would justify another class of public spending besides the two cases listed above.

I believe that, in general, the government should allocate funds to programs that either cannot be entrusted to private organizations—such as police and emergency services—or are vital for a free economy, like public roads and ports. However, a federal postal service does not fit into either of these categories, as it is not essential for preventing monopolies, and private companies have already demonstrated their ability to manage this business effectively. While it may have been necessary in the past, it has now become a relic and a misuse of resources. In this context, the best CMVs would require justification for a new category of public spending beyond the two examples mentioned.

They have greatly increased the life-expectancy of those of us who live in "advanced" countries, but they have destabilized society, have made life unfulfilling, have subjected human beings to indignities, have led to widespread psychological suffering (in the Third World to physical suffering as well) and have inflicted severe damage on the natural world. The continued development of technology will worsen the situation. It will certainly subject human beings to greater indignities and inflict greater damage on the natural world, it will probably lead to greater social disruption and psychological suffering, and it may lead to increased physical suffering even in "advanced" countries.

Technological advancements have significantly extended the life expectancy of individuals in "advanced" countries. However, they have also destabilized society, rendered life unfulfilling, subjected people to indignities, and contributed to widespread psychological suffering—along with physical suffering in the Third World. Furthermore, these advancements have severely harmed the natural environment. The ongoing development of technology is likely to exacerbate these issues. It is certain to subject individuals to even greater indignities and cause further damage to the natural world. Additionally, it will probably lead to increased social disruption and psychological distress, and it may even result in heightened physical suffering in "advanced" countries.

Technological advancements have significantly increased life expectancy in "advanced" countries. However, they have also destabilized society, rendered life less fulfilling, subjected individuals to indignities, and contributed to widespread psychological suffering—alongside physical suffering in the Third World. Moreover, these advancements have had a detrimental impact on the natural environment. The continued development of technology is likely to exacerbate these challenges, subjecting individuals to even greater indignities and inflicting further harm on the natural world. Additionally, it is expected to lead to increased social disruption and psychological distress, and may even result in heightened physical suffering in "advanced" countries.

However, they have also destabilized society, diminished the quality of life, subjected individuals to indignities, and contributed to widespread psychological distress, alongside physical suffering in the Third World. Furthermore, these advancements have negatively impacted the natural environment. The ongoing development of technology is likely to worsen these issues, leading to greater indignities for individuals and further harm to the natural world. Additionally, it is anticipated to result in increased social disruption and psychological strain, and may even heighten physical suffering in "advanced" countries.

I believe that nature will always balance itself in the end. I also believe that there is no "correct" ecosystem for an area and it is pointless to try and prevent one from changing. For example: if a species of animal were to go extinct, it may have a huge impact on the ecosystem it is home to. However, once this animal is gone, the environment will change and adapt and will still be an ecosystem in the end. The same can be said for global warming. Even if the temperatures change and the water levels of earth rise, it will create new environments and opportunities for other species of animal to take over. I can't think of a scenario where nature won't eventually take itself back. Change my view please.

I believe that nature ultimately finds a way to restore balance over time. I also hold the view that there is no definitive "correct" ecosystem for a given area, and attempting to prevent natural changes is often futile. For instance, if a particular animal species were to go extinct, it could significantly affect its local ecosystem. However, once that species is gone, the environment will adapt and evolve, continuing to function as an ecosystem. The same principle applies to global warming: even if temperatures rise and sea levels increase, these changes will lead to the emergence of new environments and opportunities for other species to thrive. I struggle to envision a scenario where nature does not eventually reclaim its balance. Please help me reconsider this perspective.

Imagine if you could have a turtle with a chicken head just wandering about your house. Sure the research would cost a lot and some animals might get hurt but I really feel the end result would be worth it.

I don't subscribe to the "don't play God" argument; I'm not concerned about divine retribution for creating such unique beings. While the research would require substantial funding and there may be risks to some animals, I truly believe the potential outcomes would be worth it.

I believe a lot people look up to models portrayed in magazines, especially teenage girls. When their "role models" are as skinny as sticks and their photos have been photoshopped and fiddled with. Teenagers want to look like the people they see in their magazines, which is a problem, because it creates a wrong image of the reality. Alot of people think that this is the standard of how you should look even though the people portrayed have been training for years and eat about 50 calories a day. With these images pushed and forced in to peoples lives, you question if you are good enough yourself. Therefore, leading to anorexia etc.

Many people, particularly teenage girls, look up to the models featured in magazines. Unfortunately, these "role models" often have unrealistic body types, appearing as skinny as sticks, and their images are frequently altered through Photoshop and other editing techniques. Teenagers aspire to emulate the figures they see in these publications, which poses a significant problem, as it distorts their perception of reality. Many individuals mistakenly believe that these images represent the standard of beauty, despite the fact that the models often undergo years of rigorous training and consume as few as 50 calories a day. The constant bombardment of these idealized images can lead people to question their own self-worth, contributing to serious issues such as anorexia and other eating disorders.

I think that it should be required to vote (either at a polling station, on-line or by post). If a person doesn't care particularly in favour of any option, they can vote "impartial" but they can't just not show up. If they don't bother to vote, they should be fined.

I believe that voting should be mandatory, whether at a polling station, online, or by mail. If someone does not have a strong preference for any option, they can choose to vote "impartial." However, they should not be allowed to simply abstain from voting. If individuals fail to participate in the voting process, they should face a fine.

Don't get me wrong, the loss of life is tragic and the aftermath of the bombing was scary. But 3 people died and 260 were injured. I tend to look at this as senseless violence, no worse than someone getting shot in Chicago or Baltimore. There were 415 homicides in Chicago last year and 516 the year before. Yet we coin phrases like "Boston Strong" and are outraged by a simple act of Islamic extremism. We have come to expect that hundreds of people will die in major cities every year but when the violence is unexpected everyone freaks out. I understand that bombings are unexpected and that the subsequent manhunt paralyzed the city with fear but I can honestly not understand why some view it as so devastating. Please change my view.

I understand that we should refrain from eating endangered species, but I'm willing to try anything once. I've eaten many kinds of game critters, sea creatures and winged animals, as well as insects. From a purely predatory point of view, I think humans should be able to eat anything they can catch. And if we're gonna eat them anyway, we might as well use their pelt and other things we can harvest from them. From the same viewpoint, I see it as purely natural when a human is eaten by, say, a bear or a shark. Fair's fair.

I recognize the importance of avoiding the consumption of endangered species, but I believe in the principle of trying new things at least once. I have sampled a variety of game animals, seafood, birds, and even insects. From a purely predatory perspective, I think humans should be able to eat anything they can catch. If we are going to consume these creatures, we should also utilize their pelts and other harvestable resources. In the same vein, I view it as a natural occurrence when a human becomes prey for a bear or a shark. After all, it’s a matter of balance in nature.

Public universities to0 often disregard first amendment freedoms by setting up freedom of speech zones and strict student handbook codes. They created these because they were overly concerned with people becoming offended. This goes against what higher education was created for and nullifies their role as a sounding board for ideas and change. The problem is such an issue organizations like the Foundation For Individual Rights In Education have been created The Christian organization Alliance Defending Freedom has responded to many college campus speech violations in the last few years We need to tackle this trend before it becomes more commonplace then it already is. Edit: Grammer

Public universities too often overlook First Amendment freedoms by establishing "free speech zones" and enforcing strict codes in student handbooks. These measures stem from an excessive concern about offending individuals, which undermines the fundamental purpose of higher education and diminishes their role as platforms for the exchange of ideas and advocacy for change. This issue has prompted the creation of organizations such as the Foundation for Individual Rights in Education. Additionally, the Christian organization Alliance Defending Freedom has addressed numerous violations of free speech on college campuses in recent years. It is crucial that we confront this trend before it becomes even more entrenched.

Furthermore, the Christian organization Alliance Defending Freedom has recently highlighted numerous instances of free speech violations on college campuses. It is essential that we confront this issue before it becomes further entrenched.

Restaurants aren't required to list ingredients because it would be very involved to list every single ingredient that is in each serving and dishes are not made from a factory; they are made subjectively and may vary from dish to dish. Some restaurants also use prepared ingredients which have their own ingredient list. The whole thing would be so long that it'd be too cumbersome to read anyway. They aren't required to list percentages as long as they are listed in order of abundance. The percentages aren't normally listed because usually they don't like to list numbers since batches may have minor variations between each others and listing a number makes it a hard value; if it is not that value then they listed incorrect information and could be held liable.

Restaurants are not obligated to provide a detailed ingredient list for each dish, as doing so would be quite complex. Dishes are prepared individually and can vary significantly from one serving to another. Additionally, many restaurants utilize pre-prepared ingredients that come with their own ingredient lists. As a result, the comprehensive list of ingredients could become excessively lengthy and cumbersome to read. While restaurants must list ingredients in order of abundance, they are not required to provide specific percentages. The absence of percentages is often due to the variability in batches; if a restaurant lists a specific number and it later proves inaccurate, they could be held liable for providing incorrect information.

Completely different types of memory. Flash memory is incredibly simple, low power, and doesn't lose it's state. The problem is it is incredibly slow (at least as far as circuits go). We also are pretty good at stacking flash memory, as heat really isn't a concern due to the low amount of operations. RAM really isn't stacked. It's built for speed, so it isn't just a gigantic NAND or NOR array. Because it operates fast, it draws a lot of current and gets pretty hot. So you can only put so much in an area and still adequately cool it.

Flash memory and RAM are fundamentally different types of memory. Flash memory is remarkably simple, energy-efficient, and retains its state even when power is lost. However, it is relatively slow compared to other circuit types. On the positive side, we have become adept at stacking flash memory, as heat is not a significant issue due to the low number of operations it performs. In contrast, RAM is not typically stacked. It is designed for speed, which means it is not merely a large NAND or NOR array. Because of its rapid operation, RAM consumes a substantial amount of current and generates considerable heat. As a result, there are limits to how much RAM can be placed in a given area while still maintaining adequate cooling.

Flash memory and RAM are fundamentally distinct types of memory. Flash memory is notably simple, energy-efficient, and retains data even when power is lost. However, it is relatively slower compared to other types of circuits. On the upside, we have become skilled at stacking flash memory, as heat generation is not a major concern due to its low operational frequency. In contrast, RAM is typically not stacked. It is engineered for speed, which means it is not just a large NAND or NOR array. Because of its high-speed operation, RAM consumes a significant amount of current and generates considerable heat. Consequently, there are limits to how much RAM can be accommodated in a given area while ensuring adequate cooling.

High inequality leads to low consumption by poor people (since they don't have much money) while the rich are more likely to save their dollars, rather than spend them, dragging down growth. High inequality also leads to many people taking on debt, creating financial instability

High levels of inequality result in reduced consumption among the poor, as they have limited financial resources. In contrast, the wealthy tend to save their money rather than spend it, which hampers economic growth. Additionally, significant inequality often forces many individuals to incur debt, contributing to financial instability.

depends on what you mean smell. It could be the smell you get after you leave the area, as the smell gets stuck to your clothes. or the tiny tiny amount of air that would normally diffuse in and out of your nostril that lets you smell it', "If you're not inhaling, you smell almost nothing. Air needs to impact your olfactory nerves to register. So if you smell it, it might be because you're expecting to smell it? Or, like uOldBirdWing mentioned, it could be sticking to your clothes.,The chemicals from cigarette smoke gets trapped in material (most likely fabric of some sort) and diffuses which is why you smell it.

It depends on what you mean by "smell." It could refer to the scent that clings to your clothes after you leave an area, or it might be the very small amount of air that diffuses into your nostrils, allowing you to perceive the scent. If you’re not inhaling, you will hardly smell anything at all; air needs to interact with your olfactory nerves for you to register a scent. So, if you notice a smell, it might be because you expect to smell it. Alternatively, as uOldBirdWing mentioned, the odor could be adhering to your clothing. The chemicals from cigarette smoke tend to get trapped in materials—most likely fabric—and then diffuse, which is why you can detect the smell.

The meaning of "smell" can vary. It might refer to the scent that lingers on your clothes after you've left a location, or it could describe the minute amount of air that enters your nostrils, enabling you to perceive a fragrance. If you’re not inhaling, you’re unlikely to detect much scent at all; air must interact with your olfactory nerves for you to register an aroma. Therefore, if you notice a smell, it may be influenced by your expectation of it. Alternatively, as uOldBirdWing pointed out, the odor could be clinging to your clothing. Cigarette smoke chemicals tend to get trapped in materials—particularly fabrics—and then diffuse, which is why you can sense the smell.

Consequently, if you become aware of a smell, it may be influenced by your expectations. Alternatively, as uOldBirdWing noted, the odor could be lingering on your clothing. Chemicals from cigarette smoke often become trapped in materials—especially fabrics—and then gradually diffuse, which is why you can smell it.

As a result, your perception of a smell can be influenced by your expectations. Furthermore, as uOldBirdWing points out, odors can linger on your clothing. Chemicals from cigarette smoke often become trapped in materials—especially fabrics—and gradually diffuse, which is why you can still detect the scent.

There's loads of different ways to pop or equalise your ears to the water pressure. The normal one we use would be pinch your nose and I'm guessing that's what you're expecting them to do. However its not really effective when you are free diving (waste of energyoxygen to move your arms up and down to the face every 2-3m) so what most freedivers do is either use a really strong nose clip that will equalise their ears when they try and blow out their nose or jaw wriggling technique (I personally haven't mastered this one) Source: scuba instructor and free dive as a hobby

There are several methods to equalize your ears in response to water pressure. The most common technique is pinching your nose, which I assume is what you're expecting. However, this method is not very effective while free diving, as it can waste energy and oxygen by requiring you to move your arms up and down to your face every 2-3 meters. Instead, many freedivers opt for a strong nose clip that allows them to equalize their ears by blowing out through their nose, or they use a jaw-wriggling technique (which I personally haven't mastered). Source: Scuba instructor and recreational freediver.

There are several techniques to equalize your ears in response to water pressure. The most widely recognized method is pinching your nose, which you might be expecting. However, this technique is not very effective while free diving, as it can lead to unnecessary energy and oxygen expenditure by requiring you to move your arms to your face every 2-3 meters. Instead, many freedivers prefer using a sturdy nose clip that allows them to equalize their ears by exhaling through their nose, or they employ a jaw-wriggling technique, which I personally have yet to master. Source: Scuba instructor and recreational freediver.

Consequently, many freedivers prefer using a sturdy nose clip, which enables them to equalize their ears by exhaling through their nose. Others employ a jaw-wriggling technique, which I have yet to master myself. Source: Scuba instructor and recreational freediver.

Your eye is not a sphere. The lens sticks out from the eyeball, and contacts are fit to that shape.', "Your eye isn't a neat spherical shape. The cornea forms a bulge that juts forward from the front of the eye. Contact lenses are shaped to fit snugly over this bulge, which means they don't fit properly on the rest of the eyeball. So if they get jarred out of position, they'll slide around on the eye until they find their way back into position on the bulge again.

Your eye is not a perfect sphere. The cornea protrudes from the front of the eye, creating a bulge. Contact lenses are designed to conform to this shape, which means they do not fit uniformly over the entire surface of the eyeball. If the lenses are dislodged, they may shift around until they realign with the bulge of the cornea.

The human eye is not a perfect sphere; rather, the cornea bulges outward from the front, creating a distinct shape. Contact lenses are crafted to accommodate this curvature, meaning they do not sit evenly across the entire surface of the eye. If the lenses become displaced, they may shift until they realign with the corneal bulge.

In many areas there is only one ISP available, or only a limited few.','It's a very large country, and installing the necessary infrastructure to give everyone whatever qualifies as "fast" service would take large amounts of time and money. Also, Internet service is provided by independent companies rather than a government-operated telecoms organization. These companies aren't jumping at the chance to increase speeds unless there's clear profit in it for them.

Limited competition exists in many regions, where only a single Internet Service Provider (ISP) or a small number of providers are available. These companies are generally reluctant to enhance speeds unless there is a clear financial incentive for them to do so.

When you speak you hear your voice through the air, but some sound waves also travel through your jaw bone and skull to your ear, which adds a bass-y note to your voice. That's why your voice recorded always sounds higher and tinnier than how you hear it.

IN most countries and us states serious crimes have no statute of limitations. Korea is different as they recently went from a 15 year to 25. I know that in Virginia rape went from a statue of limitations to unlimited as there was a man involved in a 12 step program who made apologies to a victim as part of his sobriety and that was admissible.

In Virginia, the statute of limitations for rape has been eliminated entirely. This change was influenced by a case in which a man participating in a 12-step program made apologies to his victim as part of his journey to sobriety, and those apologies were deemed admissible in court.

The Russian Ruble apparently refers to a slice taken from a silver ingot. The Japanese Yen, Chinese Yuan, and the Korean Won all refer to a "round," the typical shape of a coin. Additionally, the Japanese Yen, Chinese Yuan, and Korean Won all refer to a "round," reflecting the typical shape of coins.

Not a biologist, but how it's been explained to me: Whenever a cell reproduces, the DNA replicates. However, DNA replication is imperfect, and you usually wind up losing some off the ends of the DNA strands. At the end of each strand of DNA are telomeres, which are basically useless bits of genetic code. They serve as kind of a buffer in the replication. As you age, the telomeres get shorter due to imperfect replication, and then once you start losing relevant DNA is when you start to have major bodily breakdowns.

While I am not a biologist, here’s how it has been explained to me: Whenever a cell reproduces, its DNA undergoes replication. However, this process is not perfect, often resulting in the loss of some segments from the ends of the DNA strands. At the ends of each DNA strand are telomeres, which consist of essentially non-functional genetic material. They act as a buffer during replication. As we age, these telomeres shorten due to the imperfections in the replication process. It is only when we begin to lose essential DNA that significant bodily breakdowns occur.

Batteries (or cells if you're pedantic) work by a chemical reaction between two different electrodes. Once the reaction has progressed as far as it can, the battery is discharged. Chargers reverse the chemical reaction by applying a higher voltage to the cell than the cell generates on its own. When the battery is fully charged, the charger must stop or it will start to release gas and damage the cell. Charge termination detection is different for different types of cells.

Batteries (or cells, if you prefer a more precise term) operate through a chemical reaction between two distinct electrodes. Once this reaction has reached its maximum progression, the battery becomes discharged. Chargers facilitate the reversal of this chemical reaction by applying a higher voltage to the cell than it can produce on its own. It is crucial for the charger to cease operation once the battery is fully charged; otherwise, it may begin to release gas and potentially damage the cell. The methods for detecting charge termination vary among different types of cells.

There are several types of tears we are able to produce which contain water and oily compounds: 1. Those always present that keep our eyes moist. 2. Tears produced through irritation, rubbing intended to help flush the object out. 3. Tears produced during intense emotion. These have been shown to contain amounts of neurotransmitters. Your bodies way of dumping excess amounts of thesehelping regulate itself. It's why people report feeling better sometimes after "having a good cry

We can produce several types of tears that contain both water and oily compounds: 1. The basal tears that are constantly present to keep our eyes moist. 2. Reflex tears, which are produced in response to irritation, such as rubbing the eyes, to help flush out foreign objects. 3. Emotional tears, which are generated during moments of intense emotion and have been found to contain various neurotransmitters. This process serves as the body's way of eliminating excess amounts of these substances, helping to regulate itself. This is why many people report feeling better after "having a good cry."

We produce several types of tears that contain both water and oily compounds: 1. Basal tears, which are always present to keep our eyes moist. 2. Reflex tears, produced in response to irritation—such as when we rub our eyes—to help flush out foreign objects. 3. Emotional tears, generated during moments of intense emotion, which have been shown to contain various neurotransmitters. This process helps the body eliminate excess amounts of these substances, contributing to self-regulation. This is why many people report feeling better after "having a good cry."

When you're dead, you're not eating any more sugar.," "Because no dead person is cramming their craw full of Reese's Peanut Butter Cups and Mountain Dew.," "When you are alive, your mouth is usually warm and wet. A breeding ground for the bacteria that produce the acids that rot your teeth. pair that with eating and you make the perfect environment to rot your teeth. when you die, you take away that environment and have a dry mouthskull that doesn't breed acid producing bacteria

When you're dead, you no longer consume sugar. No deceased individual is indulging in Reese's Peanut Butter Cups or Mountain Dew. When you're alive, your mouth is typically warm and moist, creating an ideal environment for the bacteria that produce acids responsible for tooth decay. Coupled with food consumption, this leads to the perfect conditions for dental deterioration. However, upon death, this environment is eliminated, resulting in a dry mouth devoid of acid-producing bacteria.

When a person passes away, they no longer consume sugar. No deceased individual is enjoying treats like Reese's Peanut Butter Cups or Mountain Dew. While alive, the mouth is usually warm and moist, creating an ideal environment for bacteria that produce acids responsible for tooth decay. This, combined with food consumption, fosters conditions conducive to dental deterioration. However, after death, this environment disappears, leaving the mouth dry and free of acid-producing bacteria.

Whenever your muscles move they produce some heat. This is something you can not avoid as a lot of the muscles that move are essential to survive, like your heart, lung, controlling blood flow, digestive system, etc. Normally your body will regulate the heat to steady levels. However if it is hot outside, you lack water, you are ill, etc. then you may have problems regulating your body temperature. And the body temperature is not that far off the temperature at which proteins will start to unravel. So if your body temperature goes too high the proteins will not be able to do their job and body functions will stop.

Whenever your muscles are in motion, they generate heat—a natural consequence of their activity. Many of these muscles are vital for survival, such as those in the heart, lungs, and digestive system, as well as those that regulate blood flow. Typically, your body maintains a stable temperature through its regulatory mechanisms. However, external factors such as high temperatures, dehydration, or illness can hinder your ability to regulate body temperature effectively. It's important to note that body temperature can approach the threshold at which proteins begin to denature. If your body temperature rises too high, proteins may lose their functionality, leading to a cessation of essential bodily functions.

In this work we investigate energy efficient packet scheduling problem for the loss tolerant applications. We consider slow fading channel for a point to point connection with no channel state information at the transmitter side (CSIT). In the absence of CSIT, the slow fading channel has an outage probability associated with every transmit power. As a function of data loss tolerance parameters and peak power constraints, we formulate an optimization problem to minimize the average transmit energy for the user equipment (UE). The optimization problem is not convex and we use stochastic optimization technique to solve the problem. The numerical results quantify the effect of different system parameters on average transmit power and show significant power savings for the loss tolerant applications.

In this study, we explore the problem of energy-efficient packet scheduling for loss-tolerant applications. We focus on a slow fading channel in a point-to-point connection, where there is no channel state information available at the transmitter (CSIT). In the absence of CSIT, the slow fading channel is associated with an outage probability for each level of transmit power. Based on the parameters related to data loss tolerance and peak power constraints, we formulate an optimization problem aimed at minimizing the average transmit energy for the user equipment (UE). This optimization problem is non-convex, and we employ stochastic optimization techniques to find a solution. Our numerical results illustrate the impact of various system parameters on average transmit power and demonstrate significant power savings for loss-tolerant applications.

Our numerical results highlight the influence of various system parameters on average transmit power and reveal substantial power savings for loss-tolerant applications.

Given the non-convex nature of this optimization problem, we utilize stochastic optimization techniques to find a solution. Our numerical results illustrate how various system parameters affect average transmit power and reveal significant power savings for applications that can accommodate data loss.

We introduce and investigate a new notion of resilience in graph spanners. Let S be a spanner of a graph G . Roughly speaking, we say that a spanner S is resilient if all its point-to-point distances are resilient to edge failures. Namely, whenever any edge in G fails, then as a consequence of this failure all distances do not degrade in S substantially more than in G (i.e., the relative distance increases in S are very close to those in the underlying graph G). In this paper we show that sparse resilient spanners exist, and that they can be computed efficiently.

We present and explore a new concept of resilience in graph spanners. Let \( S \) be a spanner of a graph \( G \). In simple terms, we define a spanner \( S \) as resilient if all point-to-point distances within it remain robust against edge failures. Specifically, when any edge in \( G \) fails, the resulting distance increases in \( S \) do not significantly exceed those in \( G \) (i.e., the relative increases in distances in \( S \) closely mirror those in the underlying graph \( G \)). In this paper, we demonstrate the existence of sparse resilient spanners and show that they can be computed efficiently.

We analyze the complexity of biased stochastic gradient methods (SGD), where individual updates are corrupted by deterministic, i.e. biased error terms. We derive convergence results for smooth (non-convex) functions and give improved rates under the Polyak-ojasiewicz condition. We quantify how the magnitude of the bias impacts the attainable accuracy and convergence rates. Our framework covers many applications where either only biased gradient updates are available or preferred over unbiased ones for performance reasons. For instance, in the domain of distributed learning, biased gradient compression techniques such as top- k compression have been proposed as a tool to alleviate the communication bottleneck and in derivative-free optimization, only biased gradient estimators can be queried. We discuss a few guiding examples that show the broad applicability of our analysis.

We examine the complexity of biased stochastic gradient methods (SGD), in which individual updates are affected by deterministic, or biased, error terms. Our work presents convergence results for smooth (non-convex) functions and offers enhanced rates under the Polyak-ojasiewicz condition. We quantify the impact of bias magnitude on achievable accuracy and convergence rates. Our framework encompasses various applications where either only biased gradient updates are available or where they are preferred over unbiased ones for performance optimization. For example, in distributed learning, biased gradient compression techniques, such as top-k compression, have been introduced to alleviate communication bottlenecks. Additionally, in derivative-free optimization, only biased gradient estimators can be utilized. We provide several guiding examples that illustrate the wide applicability of our analysis.

We present a novel algorithm for instrumental variable (IV) regression, DualIV, which simplifies traditional two-stage methods via a dual formulation. Inspired by problems in stochastic programming, we show that the two-stage procedure for nonlinear IV regression can be reformulated as a convex-concave saddle-point problem. Our formulation circumvents the first-stage regression which is a potential bottleneck in real-world applications. Based on this new approach, we develop a simple kernel-based algorithm with a closed-form solution. Empirical results show that we are competitive to existing, more complicated algorithms for instrumental variable regression.

We introduce DualIV, an innovative algorithm for instrumental variable (IV) regression that streamlines traditional two-stage methods through a dual formulation. Drawing inspiration from stochastic programming challenges, we demonstrate that the two-stage process for nonlinear IV regression can be restructured as a convex-concave saddle-point problem. This reformulation eliminates the need for the first-stage regression, which often poses a bottleneck in practical applications. Building on this novel approach, we present a straightforward kernel-based algorithm with a closed-form solution. Empirical results indicate that our method is competitive with existing, more complex algorithms for instrumental variable regression.

We present DualIV, an innovative algorithm for instrumental variable (IV) regression that simplifies traditional two-stage methods through a dual formulation. By drawing inspiration from stochastic programming challenges, we show that the two-stage process for nonlinear IV regression can be restructured as a convex-concave saddle-point problem. This reformulation removes the necessity for the first-stage regression, which often acts as a bottleneck in practical applications. Based on this novel approach, we introduce a straightforward kernel-based algorithm that offers a closed-form solution. Empirical results demonstrate that our method is competitive with existing, more complex algorithms for instrumental variable regression.

We explore the design of an effective crowdsourcing system for an M -ary classification task. Crowd workers complete simple binary microtasks whose results are aggregated to give the final decision. We consider the scenario where the workers have a reject option so that they are allowed to skip microtasks when they are unable to or choose not to respond to binary microtasks. We present an aggregation approach using a weighted majority voting rule, where each worker's response is assigned an optimized weight to maximize crowd's classification performance.

We investigate the design of an efficient crowdsourcing system for an M-ary classification task. In this system, crowd workers perform straightforward binary microtasks, and their results are aggregated to produce the final decision. We take into account a scenario in which workers have the option to reject tasks, allowing them to skip microtasks if they are unable or choose not to respond. We propose an aggregation method utilizing a weighted majority voting rule, where each worker's response is assigned an optimized weight to enhance the overall classification performance of the crowd.

We explore the design of an efficient crowdsourcing system tailored for an M-ary classification task. In this system, crowd workers engage in simple binary microtasks, and their contributions are aggregated to reach a final decision. We consider a scenario where workers have the option to decline tasks, enabling them to skip microtasks if they are unable or prefer not to participate. To improve the overall classification performance of the crowd, we propose an aggregation method based on a weighted majority voting rule, assigning optimized weights to each worker's responses.

To enhance the overall classification performance of the crowd, we propose an aggregation method grounded in a weighted majority voting rule, which assigns optimized weights to each worker's responses.

M. Levin defined a real number x that satisfies that the sequence of the fractional parts of ( 2 n x) n 1 are such that the first N terms have discrepancy O ( (log N) 2 N), which is the smallest discrepancy known for this kind of parametric sequences. In this work we show that the fractional parts of the sequence ( 2 n x) n 1 fail to have Poissonian pair correlations. Moreover, we show that all the real numbers x that are variants of Levin's number using Pascal triangle matrices are such that the fractional parts of the sequence ( 2 n x) n 1 fail to have Poissonian pair correlations.

M. Levin defined a real number \( x \) for which the sequence of fractional parts of \( (2^n x)_{n=1}^\infty \) exhibits a discrepancy of \( O((\log N)^2 N) \) for the first \( N \) terms. This represents the smallest known discrepancy for such parametric sequences. In this work, we demonstrate that the fractional parts of the sequence \( (2^n x)_{n=1}^\infty \) do not exhibit Poissonian pair correlations. Furthermore, we establish that all real numbers \( x \) derived as variations of Levin's number using Pascal triangle matrices also fail to show Poissonian pair correlations in their corresponding sequences.

We propose a novel measure to quantify dismantlement of a fragmented network. The existing measure of dismantlement used to study problems like optimal percolation is usually the size of the largest component of the network. We modify the measure of uniformity used to prove the Szemeredi's Regularity Lemma to obtain the proposed measure. The proposed measure incorporates the notion that the measure of dismantlement increases as the number of disconnected components increase and decreases as the variance of sizes of these components increases.

We introduce a new metric for quantifying the dismantlement of a fragmented network. Traditionally, the dismantlement measure utilized in studies of optimal percolation focuses on the size of the network's largest component. Our approach adapts the uniformity measure used in proving Szemerédi's Regularity Lemma to develop this new metric. The proposed measure reflects the idea that dismantlement increases with the number of disconnected components while decreasing as the variance in the sizes of these components rises.

We present a novel metric for quantifying the dismantlement of a fragmented network. Traditionally, studies on optimal percolation have employed a dismantlement measure that centers on the size of the largest component within the network. In contrast, our approach leverages the uniformity measure utilized in the proof of Szemerédi's Regularity Lemma to formulate this new metric. This proposed measure embodies the concept that dismantlement intensifies with the number of disconnected components, while it diminishes as the variance in the sizes of these components increases.

Industry 4.0 is becoming more and more important for manufacturers as the developments in the area of Internet of Things advance. Another technology gaining more attention is data stream processing systems. Although such streaming frameworks seem to be a natural fit for Industry 4.0 scenarios, their application in this context is still low. The contributions in this paper are threefold. Firstly, we present industry findings that we derived from site inspections with a focus on Industry 4.0. Moreover, our view on Industry 4.0 and important related aspects is elaborated. As a third contribution, we illustrate our opinion on why data stream processing technologies could act as an enabler for Industry 4.0 and point out possible obstacles on this way.

Industry 4.0 is becoming increasingly significant for manufacturers as advancements in the Internet of Things continue to progress. Another technology gaining prominence is data stream processing systems. While streaming frameworks appear to be a natural fit for Industry 4.0 scenarios, their adoption in this context remains limited. This paper presents three key contributions. First, we share insights derived from site inspections that focus on Industry 4.0. Additionally, we elaborate on our perspective regarding Industry 4.0 and its important related aspects. Finally, we discuss why data stream processing technologies could serve as a catalyst for Industry 4.0 and highlight potential challenges that may arise along the way.

First, we provide insights from site inspections focused on Industry 4.0. Second, we elaborate on our perspective regarding Industry 4.0 and its key related aspects. Finally, we discuss how data stream processing technologies could act as a catalyst for Industry 4.0, as well as the potential challenges that may arise along the way.

Despite their apparent suitability for Industry 4.0 applications, the adoption of streaming frameworks in this domain remains limited. This paper presents three key contributions. First, we share insights from site inspections focused on Industry 4.0. Second, we articulate our perspective on Industry 4.0 and its essential components. Finally, we explore how data stream processing technologies could serve as a catalyst for Industry 4.0, while also addressing the potential challenges that may arise in this context.

Network densification and heterogenisation through the deployment of small cellular access points (picocells and femtocells) are seen as key mechanisms in handling the exponential increase in cellular data traffic. Modelling such networks by leveraging tools from Stochastic Geometry has proven particularly useful in understanding the fundamental limits imposed on network coverage and capacity by co-channel interference. Most of these works however assume infinite sized and uniformly distributed networks on the Euclidean plane. In contrast, we study finite sized non-uniformly distributed networks, and find the optimal non-uniform distribution of access points which maximises network coverage for a given non-uniform distribution of mobile users, and vice versa .

We identify the optimal non-uniform distribution of access points that maximizes network coverage for a given non-uniform distribution of mobile users, and conversely.

Many continuous control tasks have bounded action spaces. When policy gradient methods are applied to such tasks, out-of-bound actions need to be clipped before execution, while policies are usually optimized as if the actions are not clipped. We propose a policy gradient estimator that exploits the knowledge of actions being clipped to reduce the variance in estimation. We prove that our estimator, named clipped action policy gradient (CAPG), is unbiased and achieves lower variance than the conventional estimator that ignores action bounds. Experimental results demonstrate that CAPG generally outperforms the conventional estimator, indicating that it is a better policy gradient estimator for continuous control tasks. The source code is available at .

Many continuous control tasks involve bounded action spaces. When applying policy gradient methods to these tasks, it is necessary to clip out-of-bound actions before execution, while policies are typically optimized under the assumption that actions are unbounded. We introduce a policy gradient estimator that leverages the knowledge of action clipping to reduce estimation variance. We demonstrate that our estimator, called the Clipped Action Policy Gradient (CAPG), is unbiased and achieves lower variance compared to the conventional estimator that disregards action bounds. Experimental results show that CAPG generally outperforms the conventional estimator, highlighting its superiority as a policy gradient estimator for continuous control tasks. The source code is available at [link].

We study the metric facility location problem with client insertions and deletions. This setting differs from the classic dynamic facility location problem, where the set of clients remains the same, but the metric space can change over time. We show a deterministic algorithm that maintains a constant factor approximation to the optimal solution in worst-case time O (2 O ( 2 per client insertion or deletion in metric spaces while answering queries about the cost in O (1) time, where denotes the doubling dimension of the metric. For metric spaces with bounded doubling dimension, the update time is polylogarithmic in the parameters of the problem.

We investigate the metric facility location problem that involves client insertions and deletions. This scenario differs from the traditional dynamic facility location problem, where the client set remains constant while the metric space evolves over time. We present a deterministic algorithm that ensures a constant factor approximation to the optimal solution, with a worst-case time complexity of \( O(2^{O(d)}) \) per client insertion or deletion in metric spaces. Additionally, the algorithm can respond to cost queries in \( O(1) \) time, where \( d \) represents the doubling dimension of the metric. For metric spaces with a bounded doubling dimension, the update time is polylogarithmic in relation to the problem's parameters.

We explore the metric facility location problem, which involves both the addition and removal of clients. This scenario contrasts with the traditional dynamic facility location problem, where the set of clients remains fixed while the metric space changes over time. We present a deterministic algorithm that achieves a constant factor approximation of the optimal solution, with a worst-case time complexity of \( O(2^{O(d)}) \) for each client insertion or deletion in metric spaces. Furthermore, the algorithm efficiently handles cost queries in \( O(1) \) time, with \( d \) denoting the doubling dimension of the metric. In metric spaces with a bounded doubling dimension, the update time is polylogarithmic in relation to the problem parameters.

We study two types of preconditioners and preconditioned stochastic gradient descent (SGD) methods in a unified framework. We call the first one the Newton type due to its close relationship to Newton method, and the second one the Fisher type as its preconditioner is closely related to the inverse of Fisher information matrix. Both preconditioners can be derived from one framework, and efficiently learned on any matrix Lie groups designated by the user using natural or relative gradient descent. Many existing preconditioners and methods are special cases of either the Newton type or the Fisher type ones. Experimental results on relatively large scale machine learning problems are reported for performance study.

Both preconditioners can be derived from a single framework and can be efficiently learned on any matrix Lie groups specified by the user using natural or relative gradient descent. Many existing preconditioners and methods are particular instances of either the Newton type or the Fisher type. We present experimental results on relatively large-scale machine learning problems to evaluate performance.

This paper presents RIMAX, a new system for detecting semantic rhymes, using a Comprehensive Mexican Spanish Dictionary (DEM) and its Rhyming Dictionary (REM). We use the Vector Space Model to calculate the similarity of the definition of a query with the definitions corresponding to the assonant and consonant rhymes of the query. The preliminary results using a manual evaluation are very encouraging.

This paper introduces RIMAX, an innovative system designed for detecting semantic rhymes. It utilizes the Comprehensive Mexican Spanish Dictionary (DEM) along with its Rhyming Dictionary (REM). By employing the Vector Space Model, we assess the similarity between the definition of a query and the definitions associated with both assonant and consonant rhymes of that query. Preliminary results from manual evaluations are highly promising.

We present a game semantics for Linear Logic, in which formulas denote games and proofs denote winning strategies. We show that our semantics yields a categorical model of Linear Logic and prove full completeness for Multiplicative Linear Logic with the MIX rule: every winning strategy is the denotation of a unique cut-free proof net. A key role is played by the notion of history-free strategy; strong connections are made between history-free strategies and the Geometry of Interaction. Our semantics incorporates a natural notion of polarity, leading to a refined treatment of the additives. We make comparisons with related work by Joyal, Blass et al .

We introduce a game semantics for Linear Logic, where formulas represent games and proofs correspond to winning strategies. We demonstrate that our semantics provides a categorical model of Linear Logic and establish full completeness for Multiplicative Linear Logic with the MIX rule: every winning strategy can be represented as the denotation of a unique cut-free proof net. A central concept in our work is the history-free strategy, which reveals strong connections to the Geometry of Interaction. Our semantics also includes a natural notion of polarity, allowing for a more nuanced analysis of the additive components. Additionally, we compare our findings with related research by Joyal, Blass, and others.

Clock-dependent probabilistic timed automata extend classical timed automata with discrete probabilistic choice, where the probabilities are allowed to depend on the exact values of the clocks. Previous work has shown that the quantitative reachability problem for clock-dependent probabilistic timed automata with at least three clocks is undecidable. In this paper, we consider the subclass of clock-dependent probabilistic timed automata that have one clock , that have clock dependencies described by affine functions, and that satisfy an initialisation condition requiring that, at some point between taking edges with non-trivial clock dependencies, the clock must have an integer value. We present an approach for solving in polynomial time quantitative and qualitative reachability problems of such one-clock initialised clock-dependent probabilistic timed automata. Our results are obtained by a transformation to interval Markov decision processes.

Clock-dependent probabilistic timed automata enhance classical timed automata by incorporating discrete probabilistic choices, where the probabilities can depend on the precise values of the clocks. Previous research has established that the quantitative reachability problem for clock-dependent probabilistic timed automata with three or more clocks is undecidable. In this paper, we focus on a subclass of these automata that feature a single clock, with clock dependencies expressed through affine functions, and that meet an initialization condition requiring the clock to attain an integer value at some point while transitioning between edges with non-trivial clock dependencies. We propose a method to solve both quantitative and qualitative reachability problems for these one-clock initialized clock-dependent probabilistic timed automata in polynomial time. Our findings are derived from a transformation into interval Markov decision processes.

Clock-dependent probabilistic timed automata extend classical timed automata by introducing discrete probabilistic choices that can depend on the exact values of the clocks. Previous studies have shown that the quantitative reachability problem for clock-dependent probabilistic timed automata with three or more clocks is undecidable. In this paper, we concentrate on a specific subclass of these automata that utilize a single clock, where clock dependencies are defined through affine functions, and which satisfy an initialization condition that requires the clock to reach an integer value at some point during transitions between edges with non-trivial clock dependencies. We present a method to efficiently solve both quantitative and qualitative reachability problems for these one-clock initialized clock-dependent probabilistic timed automata in polynomial time. Our results are based on a transformation into interval Markov decision processes.

Our findings are grounded in a transformation into interval Markov decision processes.

We introduce an efficient approach to tackle both quantitative and qualitative reachability problems for these one-clock initialized clock-dependent probabilistic timed automata in polynomial time. Our findings are based on a transformation into interval Markov decision processes.

Although we have tons of machine learning tools to analyze data, most of them require users have some programming backgrounds. Here we introduce a SaaS application which allows users analyze their data without any coding and even without any knowledge of machine learning. Users can upload, train, predict and download their data by simply clicks their mouses. Our system uses data pre-processor and validator to relieve the computational cost of our server. The simple architecture of Vanlearning helps developers can easily maintain and extend it.

While there are numerous machine learning tools available for data analysis, many of them necessitate users to have a programming background. We present a SaaS application that enables users to analyze their data without any coding or prior knowledge of machine learning. With just a few clicks of their mouse, users can upload, train, predict, and download their data. Our system incorporates a data pre-processor and validator to minimize the computational load on our server. The straightforward architecture of Vanlearning allows developers to easily maintain and extend the application.

Our system features a data pre-processor and validator to reduce the computational load on our server. The simple architecture of Vanlearning enables developers to maintain and extend the application with ease.
